segments.text: Bulldog Rangers and I'm serious President Rudder had a real strong affinity for that dog and you know he was a bulldog a ranger and that's where he got his name he was a ranger so we retrieved the old dog and I guess I was the one that called the physical plant I said we're gonna have a burial for the Bulldog and we need a little maroon and white wooden coffin and
And we got him to dig a hole over here.
Do you know where he's buried?
Right over here, not far from the sidewalk.
In front of the house.
West of the house.
I mean, excuse me, east.
And we had a little ceremony.
The public was not invited.
Had buried Ranger.
And it was more emotional than I dreamed that it would be.
When...

When Mr. Rutter had a meeting with the administrators that reported directly to him, the vice presidents and so forth, we met every, we called it the executive committee, and we, what was it, every Monday?
seems like it was uh like 10 in the morning every monday i think and he presided that's correct how uh inclined was he to hear their candid opinions at that meeting i guess it depended on the uh
on the subject and whether he had already made up his mind about the way we should move.
He would very quickly let them at least sense the direction that he thought we should move.
and then introduce them and ask for their opinion.
So you would kind of plant the seed, I think.
And there were probably calls before most meetings, discussions.
And the one that he always remembered, the person of that group, deans and vice presidents and so forth, the one that he always admired was Fred Benson.

and I saw I think I saw or at least I know but I think I saw it Fred got so mad one day that he walked out of the meeting I have no recollection of what it was about but he lost his temper and instead of exploding he just said y'all gonna have to excuse me and he walked out but

people were all given a he gave everybody a chance to say something he'd go round robin you know after the business of the day what's going on over there here there and yonder but uh people he was not hard to read and people could pretty well figure out what in advance what he thought
would be the best answer.
And of course you get to know how he thinks and you can predict what you think that he would think.
And enough people were afraid of him that they wouldn't

say what they really felt sometimes was it better for one of those key administrators to speak to him one-on-one if they were in disagreement with his first judgment was it better for them to speak to him one-on-one than it was to speak at that staff meeting yes yeah i would say that's the case yeah

it goes back to his he had enough general in him that he really thought it was the wrong thing to do to publicly debate or disagree he didn't like public debate I think he would listen to anybody on anything as long as

others weren't there to hear what was transcribing and uh like i say i i i don't remember him ever losing his temper i believe you could say what you wanted to but the the press damn sure better not be there or someone that might report it and he would much prefer a one-on-one than i do you remember any occasions when you persuaded him to change his mind on a point
Not on big things like coeducation.
No.
Little things.
Kurt Ergalik, chemistry, was the coach of the soccer team.
He's from Austria, I think.
And he came to the president's office, and he said, he got an audience.
He said, President Rutter, he said,
We've been pushed all over this campus, and now they tell us that we can't play on the drill field, and we can't play here or play there.
If the weather is this way, we can't.

He says, if we took care of it, he said, could you have somebody find us a permanent place to play soccer, and it has to be somewhere close to DeWare Fieldhouse so we can take a shower and change clothes.
And so he came in and introduced me to Dr. Ergolick there in my office, and he said,
get the maps out, get with Shorty Parsons, and find this man a place to play soccer.
And I sat with Kurt, and I said, how big does a soccer field have to be?
What are the dimensions of a soccer field?
And he said, well, it's variable.
He said it doesn't, I mean, you can make it longer or shorter.
There's some, it's not all that critical.
I guess it is in World Cup, but not this.
And we had decided that this area right here, right there,
uh right to the right of that sidewalk there though it was a little unlevel he said that that would be a great place we can see the field house and
So I took the map, the plat into him, and I said, this is where we think it ought to be.
It's perfect.
And he said, he had this map.
He said, what is that in the middle of the field?
I said, well, that's a damned old mesquite tree.
He said, don't say damned old mesquite tree.
He says, where I come from?
He said, that's a tree.
He said, are you talking about they can't play around that tree?
I said, no, sir.
Somebody would run into it and get killed.
or badly injured, I said, if the tree doesn't go, we can't play this field because it's right in the middle.
He said, no, go find another place.
And I did that three times.
And finally he came in the office one day and he said, did you ever find old Ergolic, that soccer field?
I said, no, sir.
I said, there isn't one except where that old mesquite tree is.
He said, are you really serious about that?
I said, that's right.
I said, President Rutter, there is not a human on this campus that knows that tree's there except you.
I said, we can, I mean, we spend lots of money planting trees here.
We can do without that one old mosquito.
He said, you have to understand, you know, I had the driveway changed so it wouldn't tear down those two mosquitos that are over there right now by the entryway.
He had the whole thing moved, redesigned.
And he said, you talk with Shorty Parsons, and after dark some night, he said, have that tree cut down, and I want it resodded.
He said, I don't want to be a trace of that tree was removed.
And that's what happened, and we played soccer out here.
Here's what he would do.
on something like this or sometimes bigger things, I would say, well, what do you think about this approach?
No, no, no, that's not going to work.
And about a week later, he'd come in and he'd say, what did you find out about?
I said, well, don't you remember?
Our best thought was this or that, and you vetoed that.
So I'm just letting it just sit on the back.

and he'd usually on the third time he'd come in and say cooper get that tree cut down or whatever it was but he really thought things out and he knew that ecology was a big thing in the minds of people as it was when dr williams was there the green phase that we went through and he wasn't about to get
ridiculed in the paper for destroying some of God's creation right here in the middle of campus.
That's the way he thought of it.

Which of the vice presidents and other key people that reported to him, you mentioned Benson, which others, I'm only going to ask the positive, not the negative, which others did he most trust to give him good advice?
He, I think, had high regard for Wayne Hall.
There were some unfortunate things that you know about that happened within the family at other times.
But I think he had regard for him.
He thought one of his crowning achievements was bringing in a man from Columbia, namely
Ed Romanek, isn't that where he came from, Columbia?
I think so.
I believe it was Columbia.
It was his thought that this was the first breakthrough in bringing in a renowned specialist in a field as a dean.
And one of his real pet projects was to, you know, he coined the word excellence.
We want excellence at every level.
And though he made a couple of mistakes with personnel, he really thought Ed Romanek was the breakthrough on bringing people with that kind of a reputation in.

top quality that would be recognized turns out that ed had some strange little quirks but but that was that was his he really thought that was his first move towards excellence in faculty and then a couple more that were brought
It didn't pan out too well, but he really, I think, was disappointed often in the eccentricities of people of excellence.
He doesn't understand that.
They're not military people.
They don't think in that way.
They're free spirits, and he always had a hard time understanding free spirits.
Now, in fiscal matters, he had great trust in Tom Cherry and Clark Diebel.
Clark Diebel particularly.
Diebel in particular because he was in the land office.
He was in charge of all the...

uh... the book work over there and he was a good well they wasn't too wild about they'd been through german people particularly but dewa was one he liked they'd been through the courtroom stress of that uh... cleaning up that mess over there and jim lindsey of course he brought in because he had been his
PR person, his press agent in the military.
And he brought him in and and he brought in Jim Hannigan in Student Affairs because he was he was a military background.
And he brought in Shorty Parsons into the physical plant because he had a military.
His first assistant, Dorsey McCrory, was a colonel.
And so he was openly
at the non-academic level, he wanted military background people.
And I think that was part of
Why he liked me is because I was a tank platoon leader, which is about as mean and nasty as it gets.
Now, I have heard, see if you have heard this anecdote.
I've heard that when the aspirations report first came in with recommendations on the changes of coeducation, voluntary corps, integration, and so forth,
that he was taken aback by all that was in there, that he called the deans in, fussed at them, and that they tried to make excuses except for Fred Benson.
Do you know anything about that session?
Not that specifically, but the part that I do remember is the blueprint for progress was the working blueprints to implement
the study that had been done.
Isn't that right?
Right.
And I'll tell you what he really thought was that it was way out of line in terms of what it would cost.
Honestly, I think that was it.
Because it did call for some sweeping.
You're talking about library, classroom facilities.
We're talking about mega dollars.
And that scared him.
It really did scare him.
I don't think he was as mad as he was scared of what it was going to cost.
He didn't think it was that much money in the world.

Because the story I heard about that session with the deans was that Benson was the last one to speak up, that the others had made excuses, and that Benson then said, Mr. President, you asked for recommendations.
If you didn't want to get them, you shouldn't have asked.
This I remember, yes.
And then later, Rutter called him and said, thank you, Fred, I needed that.
Yes, that did happen.
Now that I think of it, it did happen.
When Mr. Rutter was getting ready to go to Austin or was getting ready to do something related to state politics, to whom did he turn for advice on those points?
Do you mean like for a budget hearing?
Budget hearing or any kind of politicking in Austin.
Well, he would talk always with the people that represented us first.
He would never go in there ignorant of what their position was and why it would have been like that.
Then he would, well, what he would find out very quickly is who's for and who's against.

whether it was our people or not but he'd call on our people to say okay what's holding us back on this who is it and then he'd work through he would work through his political system to see if they couldn't come around and he wouldn't necessarily want his name used but some cases he would but he had so many political connections in big places that
He would find out where the opposition was and try to hit it with long-range artillery, thinking of alternatives if this didn't happen.
I don't mean he was crooked about it.
He just played his politics.
Now, we didn't have, A&M didn't have a hired lobbyist then, did we?
Not that I recall.
No, and we didn't have a full-time staff member.
No.
That, in effect, he was.
He was it.
Mm-hmm.
And I don't think he would have trusted anybody else to do it.
He was smart enough.
He didn't come in on the pickle truck, and he knew that his name was Magic.
And why pay some guy even $10,000 or $12,000 a year, throwing money away, to do a job that he can do better with just a few phone calls?
And he may have been right.
And also in those olden days, the number of key people

were clearly more clearly identifiable then than they are now yeah a lot of them had long tours of duty and built up to positions you know like uh bill hobby and uh others like that and uh he knew them i mean he knew them uh whatever sources he had he knew how things were going to go and where the key uh
where the key massaging had to be done.
And that's where he'd call Boyle and Sam Wittenberg and say, look, you got an old boy out here that's really giving us hell.
They're always having trouble out around Lubbock, obviously, for obvious reasons.
And I think that's where Sam Wittenberg, if Sam Wittenberg was against someone that was a candidate for senator or what have you, they ain't going to make it.
The maddest I heard him, now on that subject, little bits and pieces come back as I talk.
He called me about 11 o'clock one night.
He said, Eddie, I'm going to call three names and you tell me which ones you've heard of.
And he called those three names, and I said, sir, I don't know anybody that you're talking about.
He says, well, that's what that goddamn Preston Smith has put on our board of directors.
He said he asked me for a short list of who to consider, and I gave it to him, and I called him when I found out what he was doing.
Peyton McKnight was one of them.
Boy, I wasn't a hill winner.
And he said, I called the governor.
I said, I don't know who these people are.
He said, how can this be?
You asked me for my list, and I gave it to you.
He says, well, there's only one difference, Earl.
He says, they were on my list, but they weren't on yours.
And that was, I'm nearly sure that was Preston Smith.
I think that's right.
I've heard many people offer great praise for John Connolly's appointment quality.
Did Mr. Rutter sometimes have an input to the governor, to Governor Connolly?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
And when he wanted somebody from the high plains,
why not pick the man that influences everybody in the High Plains every time they drink coffee?
Because he owns all the newspapers.
And Sam, I don't think Sam came to a third of the meetings, but you could call him up and say, Sam, we're still having a problem with old Senator Snart up there.
And boy, that would be over.
It was over.
When we were almost all of the board of directors, as they were then called, almost all of their meetings were here.
That's correct.
How did he prepare for those meetings?
An exchange of agenda items, first of all, on paper, as I recall.
Now, very often I wouldn't see that.
That was not part of my, he wouldn't get me involved in those things.
And he would say, you know, to Mr. Wells or whoever, Clyde, man, you're talking about a hot item there.
He said, this is not the time to have that one on that agenda.
And in those days, they would strike it.
So he would pretty well, he had a lot of influence about what the agenda would be.

then they would have a closed session and have their arguments and then they would usually have an open session or a press conference if anybody was interested and uh announced unanimous approval always unanimous approval of whatever came out so telephone and written exchange of agenda items and i'm sure well how do you how are you going to vote on this thing
And it was pretty well worked out.
And by the time they got here, they could have sat around and had cocktails because it was all pretty well done.
But their opinion really was, what can we do to support you now at this meeting?
Now, when you first went to work for him, Dr. Harrington was the chancellor of the system.
But during your years...
the system Mr. Rutter would become the chief officer of both.
Yeah, I was his assistant at that time.
Oh, that would be after you left?
Yes.
Were there some pulls and tugs between the campus president and the system chancellor when you were working for Mr. Rutter?
I think the biggest
The most controversial thing that I can remember was who the service directors reported to.
And of course that came out with later presidencies too as an issue of some import.
But he wanted control.
And part of it was that he knew that the services generally had a lot of public support, and he just wanted the university to be affiliated with all those good things that were happening out there.
And again, it's part of military.
It ought to be under the commanding general, and that's what his job was.
And let the chancellor worry about the budget and go into Austin and get the money for us with our help of course.
But those services should be under the college.
I know that athletics is now a big time consumer of any campus executive.
What about athletics in that era?
He looked at football as a potential plus factor for the reputation of the school and as just compensation for the undying generosity of its alumni.
And I think, personally, I think he overplayed the hand a little bit
Like before the Cotton Bowl game, he called Stallings, he said Stallings like no other one.
Like Jack Williams could say Pereira Review better.
But he got the team assembled after practice one day and got right out in the middle of them in the practice field.
His favorite photograph that's ever been made was him talking, giving a pep talk
to the team before they went to the 1968 Cotton Bowl game where they did beat Alabama.
And he took me with him from that game into the dressing room to thank the boys for paying so much attention to what he had said to them before the game.
But see, he had been a coach and it just was part of his bloodstream.
He wanted excellence in football.
And the other sports, he wouldn't have walked across the street for.
And didn't, as far as I can remember.
He went to the football games, particularly the home games, regularly.
But I wasn't aware that he attended many of the other sports.
Yeah, he did.
Oh, other sports?
Did not.
That's one.
And he went to nearly all of the out-of-town games.
One time he called me like on a Friday, and we were playing Texas Tech in Lubbock, and the odds were very good that we weren't going to win that game.
It had not been a good season.
And he said, how'd you like to go dove hunting?
I said, well, sure, when?
He said, we'll go out to ranch and shoot some doves tomorrow.
I said, well, sir, we're playing Tech tomorrow,
how's that going to work?
He said, I'll tell you how it's worked.
I'm sick and tired of this, getting our butts whipped, and I'm not going to love it.
He said, let's go dove hunting.
I'm not going to tell anybody where we are.
So Ms. Rutter and Peggy and I and Mr. Rutter went out there, and we shot some ducks illegally.
I did.
They were on the pond where we were shooting doves.
The doves weren't coming in, and I said to him,
Have you ever had fried duck?
He says, no, I bet that'd be good.
And I said, well, just keep your head down.
I'm going to shoot a couple.
And I did, and we had fried duck.
And he just thought that was great.
But we had a grand time.
We went to London.
He said, have you ever seen the dance hall at London?
I said, no.
He said, we're going down there and eat a chicken fried steak.
And the girls stayed at the house.
And he and I drove to London, Texas, which is about eight miles from London, eight miles to Hex, to the ranch.
It was in between.
And there was a dance hall right next door.
And while the tech kickoff was underway, he and I were at the London Cafe eating chicken fried steak.
And the band was struck up next door.
at the dance hall, and they are still there, that little dance hall.
And I said, well, you reckon the dance is in full bloom yet?
And he held his hand up against the wooden wall, and he says, no, it ain't vibrating enough yet.
He said, they're not really.
But he'd had a stomach full of it, and he didn't want to face West Texas.
And we did that several times, just escape and go out.
Alright, hunting or fishing, what other escapes were there for him from the pressures of the task?
What did he do to relax?
He'd go out to the ranch and look at the cows.
He was not gifted in any way with hunting or fishing.
He was very poorly coordinated.
Oh, so he didn't hunt or fish much?
Oh, he'd go.
Oh, okay.
But you're saying he wasn't that skillful.
He wasn't good at it.
We were down at Tennicott with an alumni board meeting.
And there's probably the best fishing lakes in Texas.
And Bob Logan and I are both fishermen.
And we'd go out and we'd catch enough fish the first morning to feed the whole group a big fish dinner.
And that afternoon, after we brought in huge stringers of fish, it was just get the hook out and know how to bring them in.
And he said, Edwin, I want you to take me fishing this afternoon.
I took him out there.
He'd cast right into the wind and the line would loop out like this.
And the fish would grab it and start off with it.
By the time he set the hook with the wind loop in it, the fish was gone.
He was just poorly coordinated.
Same with shooting the gun.
He was not good at it.
But he would go out.
We'd go to Herman Heap Place at Buda and hunt quail.
Well, that was a joke.
Or we'd fish.
And he'd sit around and talk with whoever our host was.
Then we go into Austin and go to the Hofbrau and have a big steak.
What he liked to do was have a few beers and eat a big steak.
That's how he relaxed.
Because he had no hobbies, did he?
Had no hobbies, none whatever.
He didn't.
The only collection he had was medals that he had earned.
And that was a pretty good collection.
All right, let's end this pleasant interview with at least one funny rudder story.
The best one.
And I know I've told you before, but it ought to be recorded.
I'm in his office with a happy file and a sad file one morning.
We're playing Baylor University on Saturday.
This is like Thursday.
Abner McCall calls him.
I'm in the office.
He says, keep your seat.
It's Abner.
Ms. Hott had called and told us.
And they talk business.
